>So said Kevin Klinemeier on 2003-05-06 --------------------
>
>--- "J. B. =
Rainsberger" <jbrains@...> wrote:
>> Some people will suggest using =
an instanceof check in your equals
>> method. This fails if you subclass Po=
int. 
>
>Eh?  instanceof returns true if the left-hand side argument is a
>=
subclass as well.  It also returns false if its null, which makes it
>parti=
cularly handy for objects.

The false-if-null thing I did not know, althoug=
h it makes perfect sense now that I think of it.

>If you mean that it ends=
 up breaking symmetry if subclassed, I'll
>agree.  However, as Joshua Bloch=
 pointed out (to me at least) in
>Effective Java, "There isn't any way to e=
xtend an instantiable object
>and add an aspect while preserving the Equals=
 contract".  You're either
>going to break symmetry or transitivity no matt=
er how you do it.

I read your conclusion to be that it is therefore all ri=
ght to code equals() in such a way as to report falsely that two objects ar=
e equal, because there's no way to make a superclass and subclass follow th=
e equals() contract. Is that what you are saying? If it is, then I think it=
's all the more important to implement equals() in a failsafe way, since Bl=
och claims (and I don't doubt him, but I would need to think about it) that=
 a subclass with more attributes than its superclass cannot be equal to it.=


Assuming that I did a reasonable job of expressing that, what do you say?=
